titleStmt.title: Description of Paris, BnF, MS lat. 13955

editionStmt.edition: Digital edition according to TEI P5

msDesc.head: Paris Compend Corbie s. IX (with additions till the s. XI)

msItem.note: Collection of words and their meaning. Excerpts from Priscian: Institutiones, Macrobius: Saturnalia (lib. 2, cap. 8) and others.
msItem.incipit: Somnium tegitur figuris et uelatur ambagibus
msItem.explicit: hec uocabulo dicta que ea liberi bellaria.

msItem.author: Iulius Victor
msItem.note: Excerpts from Ars rhetorica, cap. 22, 23, 25.
msItem.incipit: In his autem quae cogitamus, et in his quae scribimus retinendis proderit
msItem.explicit: et in ipsa oratione quasi quendam numerum uersumque conficere.

msItem.author: Boethius
msItem.note: Excerpt from Liber de persona et duabus naturis contra Eutychen et Nestorium (cap. 3-4).
msItem.incipit: P nabilis indiuidua sub sed nos haec definitione
msItem.explicit: duplicem quoque personam esse confessus est.
msItem.note: Some phrases written in greek characters (πρωσοπον, γποστασιν etc.)

msItem.author: Macrobius
msItem.note: Excerpt from Commentarium in somnium Scipionis (lib. 1, cap. 20, §§ 26-30).
msItem.incipit: Aequinoctiali die ante solis ortum ingens uas aequabiliter locatum saxeum
msItem.explicit: quod in cursu solis unam temporis aequinoctialis horam.

msItem.note: Later addition from s. X-XI: Hymn with Corbie interlinear neumes.
msItem.incipit: Laudes tibi mens et lingua
msItem.explicit: Cunctis monstrant inunda.

msItem.note: Anonymous poem.
msItem.incipit: Curre poema meum metaforice curre poemacamena
msItem.explicit: Hoc fiat hoc detur tribuatur ab omnipotente.

msItem.author: Hucbaldus
msItem.note: Excerpt from Musica enchiriadis, cap. 3-4, cap. 1-2.
msItem.incipit: terminales siue finales dicuntur quia in unum aliquem ex his IIIIor melos
msItem.explicit: post dicetur. Sunt etiam plura alia plurium
msItem.note: A later addition. On f. 4r partly in two columns with marginal annotations.
Originally left blank. Modern hand added a title Boetii Commentaria In Porphirium .

msItem.author: Boethius
msItem.title: In Isagogen Porphyrii commentorum
msItem.incipit: Secundus hic areptae expositionis labor
msItem.explicit: continenti rerum disputationem et ad praedicamenta seruanti.
msItem.finalRubric: Anicii mallii seuerini boetii uc et ill in isagogas porphyrii editionis secundae liber V explicit.
msItem.note: Interlinear notes, marginal Nota signes.
msItem.bibl: Boethius. In Isagogen Porphyrii Commenta. Ed. Samuel Brandt. CSEL 48. Vienna-Leipzig, 1906 (reprint 2013). Pp. 135-348.

msItem.author: Martianus Capella
msItem.note: Excerpt from De nuptiis lib. VIII De astronomia
msItem.rubric: Marciani Minnei Felicis Capelle de astronomia
msItem.incipit: Quae dum geruntur sacer senatur illos numerarum concinentium
msItem.explicit: percutiens aut in sublime tollit aut in profundum deprimit aut in latitudinem declinare aut retrogradare facit.
msItem.note: Many interlinear and marginal glosses by a different hand in a darker ink. Greek terms written in greek characters.
msItem.decoNote: Diagrams in the margins of ff. 51v and 52r showing the phases of the moon and the position of the celestial bodies during eclipse.

msItem.author: Martianus Capella
msItem.note: Excerpt from De nuptiis lib. IX De harmonia
msItem.incipit: Aurea flammigerum cum luna subegerit orbem
msItem.explicit: Fecunda redde pignora.
msItem.note: Text begins on the same new line without any rubrication.

msItem.title: Excerptum de astrologia
msItem.incipit: Duo sunt extremi uertices mundi quos appelant polos
msItem.explicit: ad ipsum usque decurrit accipiens.
msItem.note: No rubrication, a three-line high initial D.

msItem.title: De ordine ac positione
msItem.incipit: Helice arcturus maior habet stellas in capite VII
msItem.explicit: Anticanis habet stellas iii.
msItem.note: Text begins on a new line but without any rubrication. Each section is marked by a small initials, but begins on the same line as the preceding section.
Compendium of excerpts on astronomy:

msItem.author: Macrobius
msItem.note: Excerpt from Commentarium in Somnium Scipionis lib. I, cap. 15.
msItem.incipit: Sunt praeter lacteum orbes uel circuli caelo subiecti numero X. Ex quibus hic solus
msItem.explicit: hos vii circuli uelpotius globi dicant qui uersantur retro contrario motu atque celum. sed illorum longe alia ratio est.

msItem.author: Calcidius
msItem.note: Excerpt from Timaeus a Calcidio translatus commentarioque instructus, cap. 69.
msItem.incipit: Igitur fixae stellae nec errantes id est omnia signa quae superius descripta sunt
msItem.explicit: haec uaga sidera collocata sunt quorum primum ordo deinde cursus et euagatio referatur.

msItem.rubric: De ordine planetarum added in the margin

msItem.author: Macrobius
msItem.note: Excerpt from Commentarium lib. I, cap. 19.
msItem.incipit: M. tullius cicero et plinius secundus quibus archimedes et chaldeorum ratio consentit ordinem planetarum talem posuerunt
msItem.explicit: solam refundit claritudinem non calorem.

msItem.author: Pliny the Elder
msItem.note: Excerpts from Historia Naturalis lib. II, cap. 45-46, 58-61, and 63-67.
msItem.incipit: Quapropter molliore et imperfecta ui soluere tantum humorem
msItem.explicit: ad austrum descendentium aut aquilonem subeuntium.

msItem.author: Calcidius
msItem.note: Excerpt from Timaeus a Calcidio translatus commentarioque instructus, cap. 74, 85, 77-80.
msItem.incipit: Illud quoque addendum de stellis errantibus quasdam earum sequaces esse quas appelant hypolipticas
msItem.explicit: Mediae uero stature quam uelocitatis cum aut pisces aut uirginem transiet.

msItem.rubric: De uario ortu et occasu planetarum added in the margin

msItem.author: Calcidius
msItem.note: Excerpt from Timaeus a Calcidio translatus commentarioque instructus, cap. 71 and 70.
msItem.incipit: Ortus autem uarie dicitur proprie quidem prima stellarum et solis effulsio
msItem.explicit: Uenus uero prope L ad orientem occidentemque discedens.

msItem.author: Pliny the Elder
msItem.note: Excerpts from Historia Naturalis lib. II, cap. 74-78.
msItem.incipit: Hinc motuum ratio conuersa intellegitur
msItem.explicit: nullo alio in signo quam ariete conspici.

msItem.bibl: Bruce Eastwood, “Calcidius’s Commentary on Plato’s Timeus in Latin Astronomy of the Ninth to Eleventh Centuries,” in Between Demonstration and Imagination: Essays in the History of Science and Philosophy Presented to John D. North, ed. L. Nauta and A. Vanderjagt (Leiden: Brill, 1999), 171–209.

msItem.author: Boethius
msItem.title: De institutione musica
msItem.rubric: Incipit musicae institutionis liber I anicii M. S. Boetii. Proemium.
msItem.incipit: Musicam naturaliter nobis esse coniunctam et mores uel honestare uel uertere Omnium quidem perceptio sensuum ita sponte ac naturaliter
msItem.explicit: non spissis uero ut in diationicis generibus nusquam una.
msItem.decoNote: Diagrams within the texts. Marginal annotations.

msItem.author: Gerbert of Aurillac
msItem.note: Letter to Constantinus on making a hemisphere. A later addition, written by a diferent scribe using probably left blank space.
msItem.incipit: Sphera mi frater de qua queris ad celestes circulos uel signa ostendenda conponitur
msItem.explicit: nihil caeli sed terra tantum per utrasque fitulas intuenti occurrit.
msItem.bibl: Gerbert of Aurillac. The Letters of Gerbert with His Papal Privileges as Sylvester II. Tr. Harriet Pratt Lattin. New York: Columbia Univ. Press, 1961 (here pp. 36-39).

msItem.author: Fullbert of Chartres
msItem.note: Three short poems added later in the originally blank folio.
8 verses:
msItem.incipit: Libra uel a sex untiolis constat duodeni
msItem.explicit: Dimidium stater ac semuncia dicitur eius.
msItem.note: Above the text from a later hand: Libra uel a sex untiolis constat duodeni Uncia. Later erasure and additions.
8 verses:
msItem.incipit: Uncia uiginti scripulos et quatuor ambit
msItem.explicit: uigenam quartam scripulus seu gramma retentat.

msItem.note: 4 verses:
msItem.incipit: Unus item scripulus calcis conponitur octo
msItem.explicit: Ultimus est calcus ciceris duo granula pensans.

msItem.bibl: The Letters and Poems of Fulbert of Chartres. Ed. and tr. Frederick Behrends. Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1976.

msItem.author: Ps-Boethius
msItem.title: Geometria I
msItem.rubric: Incipiunt libri anicii manilii seuerini boetii artis geometriae et arithmeticae numeri V ab euclidae traslati de greco in latinum I regula artis geometriae quinque et fons sensuum et origo dictionum
msItem.incipit: Geumetria est disciplina magnitudinis immobilis formarumque
msItem.explicit: In demonstratione summitas, In conclusione extremitas.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit Anicii Manilii Seuerini Boethii liber V artis geumetriae de greco in latinum translatus ab euclide peritissimo geumetrico.
msItem.note: Added two lines Hi namque libri continent numerorum causas et diuisiones circulorum et omnium figurarum rationes extremitatum et summitatum genera angulorum et mensurarum expositiones.
msItem.decoNote: Diagrams and geometrical figures within the text body.
msItem.bibl: There is no complete edition of the Geometry I; the partial editions are listed in M. Folkerts. "Die Altercatio in der Geometrie I des Pseudo-Boethius. Ein Beitrag zur Geometrie im mittelalterlichen Quadrivium." In: Fachprosa-Studien. Beiträge zur mittelalterlichen Wissenschafts- und Geistesgeschichte, ed. G.Keil, 84-114 (esp. pp.88-89). Berlin: Erich Schmidt, 1982. Reprinted in Folkerts, Essays on early medieval mathematics, VII. Aldershot: Variorum, 2003.
See also Stevens Wesley. "Marginalia in the Latin Euclid." In Scientia in Margine, ed. D. Jacquart and Ch. Burnett, 117-138, Geneva: Librairie Droz, 2005.

msItem.note: Excerpta Agrimensorum Romanorum.
msItem.bibl: On the manuscript transmission see M. Folkerts. "Die Altercatio in der Geometrie I des Pseudo-Boethius. Ein Beitrag zur Geometrie im mittelalterlichen Quadrivium." In: Fachprosa-Studien. Beiträge zur mittelalterlichen Wissenschafts- und Geistesgeschichte, ed. G.Keil, 84-114 (esp.pp. 95-102). Berlin: Erich Schmidt, 1982. Reprinted in Folkerts, Essays on early medieval mathematics, VII. Aldershot: Variorum, 2003.
msItem.decoNote: Geometrical figures within the text body.

msItem.title: Liber podismi
msItem.incipit: Podismi mensurarum genera sunt tria· rectum, planum, solidum
msItem.explicit: Ut queramus singulas praecisuras.

msItem.title: Excerpta ex opusculo Epaphroditi
msItem.incipit: trigoni ortogonii. Cuius cathetus pedus V
msItem.explicit: erit embadum trigoni hysopleri.

msItem.title: Excerpta ex opusculo Vitruvii
msItem.incipit: Trigoni ortogoni linearum nomina· cathetus
msItem.explicit: Ut iugera inueniamus faciamus uicies XXVIII DCCC et faciunt DCXXXII que sunt XXII iugera et remanent pedes VII CCCC.

msItem.title: Excerpta ex opusculo Epaphroditi further excerpta
msItem.incipit: Sunt autem trigoni hoc genere et his uocabulis numero
msItem.explicit: Deme hypotenusam erit diametron circuli.

msItem.title: Excerpta ex opusculo Vitruvii further excerpta
msItem.incipit: Censurarum quadratarum deformatio· Mensum diuersarum ritus
msItem.explicit: Decem peda habet pedes X digitorum XI pertica habet pedes XII, digitorum XVIII.
msItem.note: Missing further sections published in Bubnov.

msItem.title: De mensura
msItem.incipit: Mensura est complurium et inter se aequalium interuallorum longitudo finita
msItem.explicit: Stadium habet pedes dcxxv, passus cxxv, miliarius habet passus pedes v stadia viii.

msItem.incipit: Mensura est quicquid pondere capacitate longitudine
msItem.explicit: palmos uncias et digitos diuiserunt.

msItem.incipit: Ponderum pars minima calculus est qui constat
msItem.explicit: Centenarius autem dicitur eo quod C libris constet.

msItem.incipit: Mensuris in liquidis coclear est pars minima qui habet dimidiam dragmam
msItem.explicit: Duo chori chulleum quod sunt modia LX.

msItem.note: Three short regula how to draw octagonal, and an octagon from a square.

msItem.incipit: Si quis uoluerit per unum latus octogonum designare ita ut
msItem.explicit: et VIII emicirculos octogonum designes.

msItem.incipit: Si quis uoluerit exagonum facere ut unum latus habeat pedes x
msItem.explicit: per extremitates circuli et erit exagonus.
msItem.decoNote: Within the text body a figure of an hexagon with semicircles on every side.

msItem.incipit: Si quis uoluerit quadratum equilaterum ostogonum facere
msItem.explicit: incidant angulos quadrati ea mensura et facies octogonum.
msItem.decoNote: Within the text body a figure of an octogonal within a square.

msItem.incipit: In pede constrato semipedes IIII. In pede porrecto semipedes duo Consuetudine uulgari unus bonuarius
msItem.explicit: de pisis tribus, de fabis tribus.
msItem.note: Perhaps a later filling-text.

msItem.author: Columella
msItem.note: Excerpt from De re rustica lib. V, cap. 1-3; VI, 29-38; XII, 6-7, 19-20, 26-27, 30, 37, 21, 5, 28(§3)-29, 32, 35 39, 46, 59, 35 - on measuring land, care of big animals, preparation of brine, wine etc.
msItem.incipit: Quoniam familiariter a nobis precepta mensurarum desideras
msItem.explicit: deinde cum refrixerit pro libito tantum portionis in amphoram musti adici.
msItem.decoNote: Drawings of geometrical figures within the body text.
msItem.bibl: Columella. Res Rustica. Ed. R. H. Rodgers. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2010, here pp. 186-196, 270-283, 491-3, 504-8, 513-8, 527-9, 550-2.

msItem.author: Isidore
msItem.note: Excerpt from Etymologiae, lib. XII, cap. 1, §§ 41 and 48-54.
msItem.incipit: Equi ab aquando dicti quia in quadrigis similes forma et pares
msItem.explicit: Qui color est medius inter nigrum et album et ab albo elbum diriuatum.
msItem.note: written by a darker ink.
msItem.bibl: Isidorus. Etymologiarum sive originum libri XX. Ed. W. M. Lindsay. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1911 (9th edition 1991), here pp. 38-40.

msItem.note: Herbarium
msItem.incipit: Bettonica a grecis dicitur cestros alii adanton
msItem.explicit: ad quartanas autem quattuor.
msItem.bibl: A. Ferraces Rodríguez, "El Herbario del manuscrito de París, Bibliothèque Nationale, lat. 13955, ff. 137v-146r. Editio princeps." Inicio 27 (2012): 197-257.

msItem.note: Collection of excerpts from Theodorus Priscianus (begins on the same line with an Initial and a marginal note "Aliud").
msItem.incipit: Vt pili ENR canis lacte si tetigeris non rescrescunt
msItem.explicit: folia imposita continui curant.
msItem.bibl: A. Ferraces Rodríguez, "El recetario Ut pili euulsi non recrescant (Paris, BNF, lat. 13955, ff. 146r-147v): extractos de Teodoro Prisciano y otras fuentes tardoantiguas en un manuscrito del s. IX." Galenos 5 (2011): 71-90.

msItem.author: Bede
msItem.note: Excerpt from De natura rerum (cap. 15 'Quare mutent colores' - on the colours of the planets).
msItem.incipit: Suus quidem cuique color est saturno candidus
msItem.explicit: orbitae actram in obscuritatem.
msItem.bibl: Bede. Opera didascalica. Ed. Charles Jones. CCSL, 123 A. Turnhout: Brepols, 1975 (here p. 207).

msItem.note: Section from Arati ea que uidentur on the constellations within the celestial circles (with minor changes).
msItem.incipit: In arctico circulo sunt signa IIII Arcturi duo cepheus a pectore draco
msItem.quote: In arctico circulo sunt signa IIII Arcturi duo cepheus a pectore draco. In aestiuus signa VIII bootes, corona, ingeniculo, lyra, cassiepia, agitator, cignus, perseus. In hiemali solstitio VI Heridanus, nauis, centaurus in quo bestia et sacrarium, piscis maior inuisibilis australis. In equinoctiali circulo XV Equus, serpentarius in quo sepens, ylidris in qua urceus et coruus, anticanis, aquila, Orion, Telum, deltoton, andromeda, lepus, coetus, canis. Unde fieri omnia signa XXXI absque eorum illustrissima alterutrum constituta uti super bootem septentrio, super agitatorem sex hedi, super taurum uergilie, super uirginem spica, super canem sirius . Zodiacus autem habet signa XII Cancrum, leonem, uirginem, libram, scorpionem, sagittarium, capricornum, aquarium, pisces, arietem, Taurum, Gemines.
msItem.explicit: Zodiacus autem habet signa XII Cancrum, leonem, uirginem, libram, scorpionem, sagittarium, capricornum, aquarium, pisces, arietem, Taurum, Gemines.

msItem.note: Section from (Ps.)Censorinus Fragmentum Censorini: De stellis fixis et stantibus, §§ 3-6 on the influence of planets.
msItem.incipit: Saturni stella frigida et sterilis terris nascentibus non salutaris
msItem.explicit: Plurimum in originibus ualent quae in ortus languent in occasu.

msItem.note: Grammatical texts, on prosody:

msItem.author: Flavius Mallius Theodorus
msItem.title: De metris (cap. 3-11)
msItem.incipit: Sunt igitur metrotum genera haec· dactilicum iambicum trochaicum anapesticum
msItem.explicit: etiam si nihil a quoquam adiciatur existiment.
msItem.bibl: Keil, Heinrich, ed. Grammatici Latini, Vol. 6: Scriptores Artis Metricae. Leipzig: Teubner, 1874 (here pp. 588-601).

msItem.author: Marius Plotius Sacerdos
msItem.title: Artium Grammaticarum (Chapter III. De metris)
msItem.rubric: Marius Plotius Sacerdos composui rome docens demetris
msItem.incipit: Cum de institutis artis grammaticae primo libro me tractauisse comperisset
msItem.explicit: Nam genus est illud asinartetum quo usa est sappho toto libro suo primo.
msItem.bibl: Keil, Heinrich, ed. Grammatici Latini, Vol. 6: Scriptores Artis Metricae. Leipzig: Teubner, 1874 (here pp. 496-546).

msItem.note: Unidetified text on metrical feet, disyllables and trisyllables.
msItem.incipit: Pedes disyllabi pirrichius spondeus iambus semper acuto accentu pronuntiabuntur
msItem.explicit: Ipsa autem positio si ex muta et liquida fuerit faciet transire acutum accentum in antepenultimas.

msItem.author: Augustine
msItem.title: De musica
msItem.incipit: Musica est scientia bene modulandi. Igitur modulatio a modo est nominata
msItem.explicit: inter istorum aequalitatem in membris imparibus et aliorum omnium intersit.
msItem.bibl: Scriptorum veterum nova collectio e vaticanis codicibus, Vol. 3. Ed. A. Mai. Rome: Typis Vaticanis, 1828 (here pp. 116-134).

msItem.note: Gromatic texts:

msItem.incipit: Castrensis iugerus quadratus habet perticas CCLXXXVIII Pedes autem quaadratos XXVIIIDCCC
msItem.explicit: hoc duco per latitudinem fiunt pedes IIICL sic quero pedaturam.

msItem.author: Balbus
msItem.note: Section from Expositio et ratio mensurarum
msItem.incipit: Gradus habet pedes IIs, passus habet pedes V
msItem.explicit: ut quinque laterum totidemque angulorum ex tri duabus rectis.
msItem.decoNote: Many geometrical figures within the text-body.
msItem.filiation: The same sections and illustrations also in Bern, Burgerbibliothek, Cod. 87, ff. 16v-17v.

msItem.author: Hyginus Gromaticus
msItem.title: Constitutio limitum (sections)
msItem.incipit: Querenda est primum que sit quae ratio oriundi aut occidendi
msItem.explicit: Nam et egypto medio die umbra consumitur ex hoc ibidem
msItem.decoNote: With diagrams: on f. 169r a planisphere showing the paths of the planets nested one inside the other and the circles of the zodiac and the horizon; on f. 169v two unfinished rota diagrams.
msItem.note: Presumably a later addition on the three lines at the bottom of the folio (left originally blank because of diagram positioned on the next page) by the same hand with a marginal nota Item aliter marking a paraphrase or a note on Augustine, De doctrina christiana, Book IV, 12, 27: Debet ita dicere sapiens, ut doceat, ut delectet, ut flectat. Docere necessitatis est, Delectare, suauitastis, Fletere uictoriae.

supportDesc.collation: 22 quires: I4 (ff.1-4), II-VII8 (ff.5-12, 13-20, 21-28, 29-36, 37-44, 45-52), VIII10 (ff.53-62), IX-XI8 (ff.63-70, 71-78, 79-86), XII10 (ff.87-96), XIII8 (ff.97-104), XIV6(-1) wants 6 (ff.105-109), XV8 (ff.110-117), XVI10 (ff.118-127), XVII-XVIII8 (ff.128-135, 136-143), XIX4 (ff.144-147), XX-XXI8 (ff.148-155, 156-163), XXII8(-2) wants 2 and 3 (ff.164-169). Quire marks with roman numerals on the lower margins on verso - 4v "I", 12v - "II" and so on.

condition.p: As is visible from marginal annotations (e.g. on f. 105v) the manuscript was cut on the sides during rebinding, so that some marginal notes were lost. A librarian note from 7. May 1884 on the front pastedown states that already at that time ff. 52-55, 59-63, 79-81, 167-169 are mutilated. Folios 49-88 are smudged on the upper outer edge due probably to water damage. More seriously damaged were ff. 52-64, and 76-81 were the upper outer corner is either smudged or missing (on f. 76v and 78v a later hand rewrote the blemished texts in the corners); ff. 168-9 have two large holes, f. 167 have smaller damages, but still misses sections of the text.

handNote.p: Written by one main hand, Hand A (characterised above all by a g with an open lower lobe extended to the left and an upright script) and several secondary hands. Hand A copied the astronomical texts (ff. 46v-60r).
All hands share similar features: e-caudata, round r after o. Ligatures: nt, ct, rt, ri, st. Abbreviations: insular h for autem, H for enim, and ÷ for est; ² for -ur, apostroph for -us.

handDesc.handNote: Later additions by another hand on f. 3r-v.
Later additions of Gerbert's letter and Fulbert's poem by an 11th-century hand (?).

physDesc.additions: On the first folio labelled A a 19th century hand added a table of content. On f. 1r possesion note mentioned below and probatio pennae.

origin.p: The manuscript was copied in several stages in the second half of the ninth century in St. Peter's Abbey in Corbie during the abbacy of Hadoard. According to B. Bischoff most of the manuscript was copied in the third quarter of the century, while ff. 46-53v with Martianus Capella's text were later insertion to the mauscript presumably at the end of the century.

Wesley Stevens ("Marginalia in the Latin Euclid" in Scientia in Margine, ed. D. Jacquart and Ch. Burnett, pp. 117-138, esp. p. 120, n. 6) suggested that ff. 114v-121v were copied by a hand with some Fulda characteristics 825-840.

Looking at the quire structure and the hands involved in the production of the manuscript it seems that Hand A played the leading role, as it was involved in the copying or later correction of all texts. The texts start only rarely at the beginning of a quire (the sole exeption being Boethius, In isagogen), and very often start middle of the folio right after the previous text ends. This inclines me to consider the codex not as a composite manuscript of separate booklets, but rather as a collection that grew in time, as Hand A and his colleagues added more and more texts producing an anthology of liberal arts.

provenance.p: The manuscript is mentioned in two abbey catalogues: in Berlin, SB, Ms. Phill. 1865, f. 2ra datable to the end of the twelfth century and in Vat. Reg. Lat. 520from around the year 1200 as Boetii commentum in isagogis et musica et geometria and commentum in isagogas Porfirii accordingly. Cf. Catalogue général des manuscrits des bibliothèques publiques de France: Départements, Vol. 19, p. XV, n° 80 and p. XLII, n° 303, Becker, n° 79 and n° 136 pp. 185-192 (here p. 187, item n° 80) and pp. 277-298 (here p. 284, item n° 278, U. Winter, Die mittelalterlichen Bibliothekskataloge aus Corbie , Berlin, Univ., Phil. Diss., 1972, pp. 10-16, 91-137 and 354-74 and Ganz, p. 37..

The manuscript was probably consulted in Chartres in the 10th or 11th century by Fulbert. It is tempting to believe that during that time the two filling text on ff. 105v-106v were copied during that period. Later on the manuscript was the property of the monastery of Saint-Germain-des-Prés (see note on f.1r.

acquisition.p: Acquired by the Bibliothèque nationale during the French revolution (see f. 1r N. 1094 and olim 544.

listBibl.head: Selected Bibliography:
